docs.abstract: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post released a statement critical of China’s revocation of Americans’ credentials.
docs.snippet: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post released a statement critical of China’s revocation of Americans’ credentials.
docs.lead_paragraph: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post on Tuesday released a statement critical of the Chinese government’s decision to bar American journalists for the three publications from working in China.

headline.main: 3 Newspapers Ask China to Reverse Decision to Expel American Journalists
headline.print_headline: 3 Newspapers Ask China to Reverse Expulsion of American Journalists

docs.abstract: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
docs.snippet: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
docs.lead_paragraph: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.

headline.main: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring

byline.original: By David Gelles and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
docs.snippet: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you couldn’t join us on Friday for our special conference call about the business and policy implications of the coronavirus pandemic, the recording is here. The response was enormous — more than 4,000 of you signed up to participate — so we couldn’t get to all of the questions. What should we cover in future calls? Let us know. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline.main: What Will Fill a $4 Trillion Hole in the Economy?

docs.abstract: More than 90 percent of the hotels in the U.S. are franchised, and these owners say their business has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.snippet: More than 90 percent of the hotels in the U.S. are franchised, and these owners say their business has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: It all started to fall apart for Vinay Patel about a week ago.

headline.main: Big-Name Hotels Go Empty and Smaller Owners Are Hurt
headline.print_headline: Empty Rooms, and Pockets, Plague Hotel Franchisees

docs.abstract: Unemployment claims are about to dwarf anything seen before.
docs.snippet: Unemployment claims are about to dwarf anything seen before.
docs.lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

docs.abstract: Businesses are grappling with how to deal with a potential outbreak. Here’s what they’re doing, and how it could affect their workers.
docs.snippet: Businesses are grappling with how to deal with a potential outbreak. Here’s what they’re doing, and how it could affect their workers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Furloughs. Sick leave. Working from home.

headline.main: Working From Home: How Coronavirus Could Affect the Workplace
headline.print_headline: Advice on Coronavirus and the Workplace

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

docs.abstract: As capital flees emerging markets, those countries are absorbing the most potent economic shocks of the coronavirus outbreak.
docs.snippet: As capital flees emerging markets, those countries are absorbing the most potent economic shocks of the coronavirus outbreak.
docs.lead_paragraph: In New Delhi, a fruit vendor whose sales have dropped by half now dilutes the milk she serves to her five children. In central Turkey, a company that runs hot air balloon rides for tourists has banished its 49 employees to indefinite leave while cutting their wages by half.

headline.main: In World’s Most Vulnerable Countries, the Pandemic Rivals the 2008 Crisis
headline.print_headline: Where Life On the Edge Just Got Riskier

byline.original: By Peter S. Goodman, Daniel Politi, Suhasini Raj, Lynsey Chutel and Abdi Latif Dahir

docs.abstract: The Federal Reserve has moved quickly to combat economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, but President Trump’s ongoing attacks may have weakened its message.
docs.snippet: The Federal Reserve has moved quickly to combat economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, but President Trump’s ongoing attacks may have weakened its message.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has spent two years publicly attacking the Federal Reserve and undercutting its chair, Jerome H. Powell. That animosity is making it difficult for Washington to project a united front as it stares down the most significant economic threat since the Great Recession.

headline.main: How Trump’s Attacks on the Fed Have Made Its Job Harder
headline.print_headline: Trump’s Attacks on the Fed Undercut a United Front in Washington

byline.original: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

docs.abstract: As the outbreak forces the cancellation of trips, nights out and large gatherings, economic damage is mounting across the country.
docs.snippet: As the outbreak forces the cancellation of trips, nights out and large gatherings, economic damage is mounting across the country.
docs.lead_paragraph: A week ago, Mark Canlis’s restaurant in Seattle was offering a $135 tasting menu to a bustling dining room every night. Eileen Hornor’s inn on the Maine coast was booking rooms for the busy spring graduation season. And Kalena Masching, a real estate agent in California, was fielding multiple offers on a $1.2 million home.

headline.main: Coronavirus Cost to Businesses and Workers: ‘It Has All Gone to Hell’
headline.print_headline: As Business Grinds to a Halt, The Cost of Disruption Surges

byline.original: By Ben Casselman, Patricia Cohen, Stacy Cowley, Conor Dougherty, Nicholas Kulish, David McCabe and Karen Weise

docs.abstract: The electric carmaker had continued making cars in recent days in apparent defiance of a local county order limiting operations of nonessential businesses.
docs.snippet: The electric carmaker had continued making cars in recent days in apparent defiance of a local county order limiting operations of nonessential businesses.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tesla, the luxury electric carmaker, said on Thursday that it would shut down production at its San Francisco Bay Area factory, which has remained open for several days in apparent defiance of a local county order.

headline.main: After Mounting Criticism, Tesla Will Shut Down California Factory
headline.print_headline: Tesla, Facing Uproar,  To Shut Bay Area Plant
